posts.cooked:
was browsing the FIRST site to check out the newly added devices on the ‚ÄúLegal Devices List,‚Äù and I found it interesting that AndyMark released a new motor controller.

I want to make it clear that I have no criticism of AndyMark as a company‚Äîmy team relies on many of their mechanisms‚Äîbut this motor controller stood out to me as a bit unusual. It seems overly simplistic for a typical 2025 FRC team. For instance, it doesn‚Äôt support CAN communication, and I wasn‚Äôt able to find a library for it.

My theory is that this is intended as a starter or more affordable controller for FRC , especially since the CTRE VictorSPX has been deprecated. However, as a veteran from a foreign team (I‚Äôm from Brazil, by the way), I find it hard to judge the price gap between controllers because everything here costs 2‚Äì3 times the U.S. price.

Again, I want to emphasize that I‚Äôm not trying to criticize AndyMark in any way. I‚Äôm just genuinely curious about this new release.

Yea, I don‚Äôt imagine they have a huge amount of market share, but there‚Äôs a ton of teams who still do their design and engineering with brushed motors, and they ain‚Äôt going away any time soon.

posts.name: Duncan Macdonald
posts.cooked:
I wouldn‚Äôt touch it with a ten foot pole. I hope it‚Äôs not in the KOP . It‚Äôs a sunk cost trap.

When $90-$120 ($80 if a nova supports brushed) buys something forward compatible with a brushless motor, a $50 dead end pwm speed controller isn‚Äôt the right choice for the top 100 percentile of FRC teams.

A ‚Äúprototyping speed controller‚Äù that‚Äôs ‚Äúavailable late January‚Äù isn‚Äôt very useful either.

Most importantly it‚Äôs just a weird product to name after a founder.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
So, what were you going to do with all those CIM and Redline motors you‚Äôve got laying around?

What would Mark do?

posts.name: Duncan Macdonald
posts.cooked:
Every shop with abundant CIMs and Redlines also should also have enough period correct Spark, Spark MAX, Talon, Talon SRX, Victor 884, Victor 888, Victor SP, SPX Motor Controllers that are laying around too.

Teams, especially ones with tight budgets, should be making purchase decisions with a multi year trajectory. Buy SparkMaxes this year and Neo v1.1s next year.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: Or find a friend with brushed motors and controllers for your superstructure so that you can run kraken drive‚Ä¶

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Sample size of one, our motor collection far outpaced our motor controller collection. I‚Äôd not be assuming that tracks 1:1.

I agree late Jan release is less than desirable.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Duncan_Macdonald:

I wouldn‚Äôt touch it with a ten foot pole. I hope it‚Äôs not in the KOP . It‚Äôs a sunk cost trap.

When $90-$120 ($80 if a nova supports brushed) buys something forward compatible with a brushless motor, a $50 dead end pwm speed controller isn‚Äôt the right choice for the top 100 percentile of FRC teams.

I think you‚Äôre ignoring just how flagrantly cheap the bottom, struggle-bus-tier teams can be.  And sometimes, have to be.  Yes, some of those teams probably should be in FTC .  But they‚Äôre here, and having a $50 option to keep them (or just a generic, non-competition robot) operational is still a good thing even if it‚Äôs got a low ceiling compared to Nova and SPARK MAX.  The net $120-160 saved over the course of a drivetrain isn‚Äôt nothing, and that‚Äôs assuming the team can even buy from other vendors under school policies.

Duncan_Macdonald:

Most importantly it‚Äôs just a weird product to name after a founder.

Mark and I were ships in the night in Kokomo; he retired from AndyMark about a month after I got there.  But it should say a bit about his approach that the last new product he really shipped while at AndyMark was a revised 8" mecanum wheel in 2016.  And mecanum was a dirty word to some teams then, to the point that the next year‚Äôs April Fools joke was selling the 4" light-duty mecanums as 4" Vectored Intake Wheels.

And, lest we forget, the TechnoKats ball drive . (And here‚Äôs a 21-year-old post from Andy talking about it.)

So a product that enables some to create interesting builds, independent of whether they are highly competitive builds, feels on brand to me.

Then again, the ball drive (loaned to 909 after a catastrophic drivetrain failure) did go 5-2-1 and notch a win over 45 in a match at the 2003 Midwest Regional .

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Not 1:1 but they aren‚Äôt wrong about them accumulating‚Ä¶ We have a giant collection of VictorSPX, TalonSRX that we only reasonably use 2-4 of each season for non-brushless mechanisms. We only used brushless for drive trains or a shooter, but brushed for anything else so we needed more of them at one point.

The one big advantage of a PWM system is it is isolated from the CAN network and for teams that struggle with secure/reliable CAN they can divert simple stuff over to PWM . If the shooter, intake, conveyor, arm, climber motor controller on CAN shuts down, is damaged, disconnected in a CAN network the rest of the devices on that network also might go down.

The PWM system goes down (usually wire disconnect), the affected motor is shut down, but the rest are unaffected in most cases. You could still drive and possibly do other actions minus one motor.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Just because something is FRC legal doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs part of the formula for a trip to Einstein.

As others have said, you can‚Äôt buy a lot of the old brushed motor controllers anymore, and they tended to burn out a lot quicker than the old brushed motors (whether by heavy use, or a student connecting power wires in reverse‚Ä¶)

Having a new, basic controller for new members to learn the magic-free (no built in sensor ports for internal PID ) fundamentals of building a robot is awesome. Once they get the hang of that, they can move up to the ‚Äúreal‚Äù stuff.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Richard_Wallace:

What would Mark do?

I‚Äôll answer my own question;  Mark Koors would:

Sketch the concept

Write the equations and do the math (model)

Make a quick and dirty prototype ‚Äì This is where low cost materials; i.e.,  cheap motors, become helpful.

Measure what the prototype does

Use the measured behavior to correct any assumptions made in step 2.

Like all great engineers, Mark knew that all models (simulations) are wrong, and that some of them are useful anyway.  The useful ones are those that have been through the steps above.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Yuri:

and I wasn‚Äôt able to find a library for it.

Since it uses PWM , a library isn‚Äôt necessary. There will be explicit support in the 2025 WPILib Kickoff release.
